publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

monogr.title: Babels balm: or The honey-combe of Romes religion : With a neate draining and straining-out of the rammish honey thereof. Sung in tenne most elegant elegies in Latine, by that most worthy Christian satyrist, Master George Good-vvinne. And translated into tenne English satyres, by the Muses most vnworthy Eccho, Iohn Vicars
monogr.author: Goodwin, George

lg.l: ONce, Satan hatch't an Egge, full of foule Hope,
Whose Birth, by Fraud and Pride became a Pope:
How fondly men breake Serpents Egges? Romes pride
Dos't to their hand, and giues a Pope beside.

lg.head: Another.
lg.l: The Popes great Pride and Pompe Emperiall,
Did make him Head, will make him head-long fal • .

lg.head: Against Papall Supremacie.
lg.l: Romes High-Priest, late, like Sol, aloft did shine,
His patent Rule, by potent Wrath diuine,
Now, turnes to Ashes; late a Cedar fall.

lg.head: Another.
lg.l: As encreast, decreast is the Popes great power:
And Rome, which flourisht, fades, now, like a flower.

lg.head: A Briefe of the Romish Religion.
lg.l: Of all Summes, here's the Summary, chiefe Summe;
That vnderneath the Popes Rule, Faiths Rule come.
